bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, August 9, 1942

div1.p: Kean writes that he has started his memoir. In a postscript, Kean explains Gorgas was excluded from the yellow fever painting because Gorgas did not initially believe in the mosquito theory.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, August 9, 1942
div1.opener:
C2
B5
2804 N St. N. W.
Washington D.C.
Sunday morning
Aug. 9, 1942.
My dear Truby
div1.p:
Please tell your bonny wife
that we have had a big easterly rain and
on Friday-no-on Wednesday I sat down and
wrote the first paragraph of the memoir, being
mindful of my promise to her on the 31st
The max. that day was 73°. But the delightful
change of temperature had started a whole
lot of other activities besides the Introduction
and for a couple of days there was a succes-
sion of callers, jobs and must do things to
keep me busy. Yesterday I refused to leave my
desk until it was finished, read over with
Cornelia for errors and comments and finally
copied. At 6.10 pm I laid down my pen and
took a good drink of Magnider's 5 year old
Bourbon. Cornelia's first criticism was that
Dr. Hench was mentioned before you were, but
I think she modified her opinion when I went
over it and showed her that the first two pages
were introductory and that I thought the review
of the entire episode which he has brought about
adds appreciably to the value of your work.
2
I think we all agree that the last dra[f]
memoir is a decided improvement over
first one and many of the suggestions are du[e]
to the sresearchesd that his questionnaires and
letters caused us to make. If however you
feel that there is too much Hench in it, you have
my permission to cut out the second page after
the 3rd line. I think however that it is quite
desirable that the readers of your memoir
should understand that a general revision of
the entire work of the Reed Board is in pro-
gress to which your memoir contribustes essen-
tial facts and points of view which could be
obtained from no other source.

I am conscious of owing you a letter on two
but hope you will forgive me as I had
another bout at Walter Reed and had no
writing material there and went into Episto-
lary bankruptcy when I came home. I
was much interested to see Siler's letter to you
advising the use of Aedes Egypti (Culex Fasciatus)
I had wondered what you should do about that.
Also I was interested in your reply to him
giving the news of Jack from West Point.
How they do work those boys! I have heard
from my grandson three times but he give very
few details. Mrs. Kean wants to be remembered
to you both. We are both very well and hope you both are likewise.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, August 11, 1942
div1.opener:
2404 N St. N. W. Washington D.C.
Aug 11, 1942
Post Script No 3.
Dear Truby:
div1.p:
I forgot one thing I intended to say
in my letter to you of Sunday until the envelope
was sealed & ready to mail.

Some one asked me why Gorgas was not among
the Yellow Fever Conquerors and it is a very
natural question. The answer is of course that on
the date celebrated in Cornwell's painting Gorgas was
not a believer in the mosquito theory and had no
share in the work of Reesd's Board except in the perform-
ance of his duty to see the cases. The conversion of
Gorgas and its date is a matter of interest and it is
not clearer and correctly stated in any of the biographies
or sketches. The facts are as follows and they are clearly
stated by Gorgas himself. He told me about Feb. 1st 1901,
just before I left for Washington, that he know that
Reed had succeeded in causing attacks of yellow fever
by the bites of infected mosquitos but he did not believe
that it was the only way or even the ordinary way of
conveying the disease. He make the same statement in
the same words as his mental attitude, when Reed
read his paper & announced the eleven conclusions
of the Y. F. Board on Feb. 4 1901, in his (Gorgas's) Final
Report as Chief Sanitary Officer of Havana dated July 12,
1902. (Senate Doc. No. 822 p. 236) The 10th conclusion in Reed's
paper was “The spread of yellow fever can be most
(over)
2.
effectually controlled by measures directed to the
destruction of mosquitos and the protection of the
sick against the bites of these insects.” Gorgas said
he had very little hope of accomplishing much in
this way, but he says the work was begun on Feb. 4.
This was manifesty a clerical error; (Reed gives the date
as Feb. 15) but Gorgas goes on to say that with only
6 deaths from March to September 1901 the result convin-
ced the sanitary department that the mosquito not
only could convey the disease but that it was the
ordinary way. Reed's fomites experiments, which
were of enormous importance, yet seemed (seemed)
to make no impression on Gorgas and he does not
mention them in his report. Altho. Havard's
Circular No. 5 Dept. of Cuba forbidding disinfectious for Y.F. was issued April 17
Gorgas evidently did not consider it as applying
to the Sanitary Department and continued to
disinfect bedding, clothing etc. until Aug. 15, 1901,
when he wrote to Reed that he had stopped it.
So I think we can use that as the date of the con
acceptance by Gorgas of the eleven conclusions of the
Reed Board. As that was a year lacking 12 days,
after the date of Carroll's infection which is celebrated
by Cornwell's painting, it is quite clear why Gorgas
could not appear in that group as one of the Con-
querors. The date of beginning the mosquito warfare
is an evidence of General Wood's belief, not of
Gorgas's. Now mind you I am not criticising Gorgas
for being somewhat conservative. Osler says that a healthy
scepticism is an important attitude of the scientific mind
but his complete ignoring of conclusion 8 I cannot understand.

closer.seg:
I do not recall whether this attitude of Gorgas was mentioned
in your memoir.
